identificationModule.briefTitle: Effects of Esketamine on Consciousness-related Brain Network Characteristics in Patients With Prolonged Disorders of Consciousness
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effects of Esketamine on Consciousness-related Brain Network Characteristics in Patients With Prolonged Disorders of Consciousness

responsibleParty.investigatorTitle: Head of anesthesiology, Principal Investigator, Clinical Professor

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Prolonged disorders of consciousness (pDoC) are pathologies in which there is a loss of consciousness for more than 28 days. The number of patients with pDoC is increasing as the level of critical care treatment and monitoring improves. However, clinical trials for patients with pDoC are limited by small sample sizes, lack of placebo groups, and use of heterogeneous outcome measures. As a result, few therapies have strong evidence to support their use. In recent years, ketamine has been used with remarkable success in the treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders by inducing neuroplasticity, increasing neurophysiologic complexity, and expanding functional brain connectivity states. Considering increased brain plasticity as well as brain complexity, it may be beneficial for consciousness recovery. In this study, the investigators aimed to explore the effects of esketamine on brain networks and level of consciousness in patients with pDoC, and to discuss its possible use as a wakefulness-promoting treatment for patients with pDoC.

armGroups.label: Patients with prolonged disorders of consciousness

interventions.name: Drug: Esketamine (Continuous infusion)
interventions.description: Continuous intravenous infusion of ketamine at a dose of 0.3mg/(kg · h). Collect resting state EEG and auditory event-related potential (ERP) before administration (baseline), 60 minutes after administration, 30 and 60 minutes after discontinuation.
armGroupLabels: Patients with prolonged disorders of consciousness

primaryOutcomes.description: A higher entropy index indicates a higher brain complexity.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the trial(up to 3 hours for each subject).

primaryOutcomes.description: Higher Lempel Ziv complexity indicates higher brain complexity.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the trial(up to 3 hours for each subject).

secondaryOutcomes.description: EEG power spectrum characteristics of pDoC patients under esketamine. administration, including the δ, θ, α, β, and γ frequency bands.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the trial(up to 3 hours for each subject).

secondaryOutcomes.description: Characteristics of the weighted phase lag index(WPLI) in patients with pDoC. 0 ≤ WPLI ≤ 1, where 0 represents asynchronous and 1 represents synchronous.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the trial(up to 3 hours for each subject.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Rate of patients recovered consciousness after surgery
secondaryOutcomes.description: Rate of patients recovered consciousness 30 days, 90 days, 180 days after surgery.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the trial(through study completion, 180 days).
